Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Current synthetic efforts in polymer chemistry are focused on preparation of materials with well-defined structures and low polydispersities. The resulting (co)polymers self-organize during processing but also often require a very narrow fabrication regime window in order to exhibit all unique properties. During the past several years, similar activities were the main of focus of many synthetic laboratories (including CMU group) and resulted in the successful development of various controlled/living ionic and, more recently, radical systems. However, it is believed that it is time to change the focus in synthetic polymer chemistry and explore synthesis of materials with controlled heterogeneities, instead of a constant race for polymers with lower polydispersities. Availability of polymers with controlled heterogeneities may lead to a paradigm shift in preparation of materials for high value applications. Three major elements of molecular heterogeneity will be explored and their effect on nanostructured morphology and consequently, macroscopic properties will be studied. They include chain uniformity (polydispersity), chain composition (gradients) and chain topology (branching and crosslinking). Intrinsic correlations between these parameters will be studied and potential synergistic interactions will be investigated. The anticipated results might have a broad impact on science, education and our society. The diminished level of catalyst in ATRP will reduce the environmental impact of transition metal catalyst and concurrently allow preparation of materials with enhanced properties. Broadened but controlled molecular weight distributions should not only provide materials with new properties but also relax the processing regime and widen the processing window.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This proposal addresses the synthesis, characterization and potential applications of polymers with controlled heterogeneities. Several components of this proposal can have an impact on science, education and our society. Teaching undergraduate and graduate students, as well as training a postdoctoral fellow and visitors from collaborative groups will take place. Members of CMU group will visit other laboratories outside CMU and will work together with members of other CMU groups. Dissemination of information will be accomplished by timely publications, presentations at (inter)national meetings and at CMU web site. Members of CRP Consortium at CMU will be encouraged to use the new technology developed in the proposed research and evaluate the new materials in their markets. The companies will benefit from knowledge generated by the NSF supported activities. The anticipated research results can impact not only synthetic polymer chemistry but also materials science and may lead to the development of commercially valuable materials such as shock absorbents, vibration and noise dampening materials, surfactants with enhanced properties, stimuli responsive hydrogels, nanoporous materials and potentially membranes with presently unattainable pore morphology.

POR.DRECONTENT: Research was focused on synthesis, characterization and potential applications of polymers with controlled heterogeneities. The main intellectual merit was to explore three major elements of macromolecular heterogeneity and their effect on nanostructured morphology and consequently, macroscopic properties. They include chain uniformity (dispersity), chain composition (gradients) and chain topology (branching and crosslinking). Intrinsic correlations between these parameters were studied to identify their synergistic interactions. The architectural imperfections were harnessed by systematic explorations of materials with controlled heterogeneities prepared under environmentally benign conditions such as aqueous media and very low concentration of Cu catalysts. These concepts were applied to synthesis of various polymers with complex architectures such as block copolymers, stars and hybrid materials, including bioconjugates but also various nanostructured organic/inorganic systems.  Materials with controlled heterogeneity generated new morphologies (hexagonally perforated lamellae), self-healing systems, materials with hierarchical porosity and new delivery agents for nucleic acid. The research carried out had a broader impact on other disciplines. New advanced materials, such as nanostructured highly porous nitrogen enriched carbons have potential environmental and energy related applications as electrodes for oxygen reduction and hydrogen evolution reactions and can replace expensive platinum in fuel cell systems. They are also excellent components of dye-sensitized solar cells and supercapacitors and can be used for fast CO2 capture. Nanogels with degradable cationic core can be used for delivery of plasmid DNA and siRNA. Macroscopic gels can self-heal and rapidly respond to environmental stimuli. Densely grafted brushes act as supersoft elastomers with modulus (stiffness) similar to hydrogels but they will never dry as the networks are diluted by covalently attached short soft chains. The project involved education of graduate, undergraduate students and postdoctoral fellows. They were exposed to the most recent and advanced synthetic techniques in radical polymerization processes and characterization of polymeric materials. They regularly presented at semiannual Consortium meetings and also at national and international symposia. Their research was recognized by several ACS awards and they started successful careers in either academia or industry. PI research was also recognized by several international and ACS awards. The main dissemination process was through timely publications: 136 papers were published in peer-review journals. Our web site is very often visited (annually over 50,000 times) and provides introductory and advanced information on various controlled radical polymerization systems. Two ACS Meetings on Controlled Radical Polymerization were organized in 2011 and 2014 with ca. 100 oral and 100 poster presentations.  Controlled radical polymerization is of significant commercial interest as evidenced by 55 internationa...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Research was focused on synthesis, characterization and potential applications of polymers with controlled heterogeneities. The main intellectual merit was to explore three major elements of macromolecular heterogeneity and their effect on nanostructured morphology and consequently, macroscopic properties. They include chain uniformity (dispersity), chain composition (gradients) and chain topology (branching and crosslinking). Intrinsic correlations between these parameters were studied to identify their synergistic interactions. The architectural imperfections were harnessed by systematic explorations of materials with controlled heterogeneities prepared under environmentally benign conditions such as aqueous media and very low concentration of Cu catalysts. These concepts were applied to synthesis of various polymers with complex architectures such as block copolymers, stars and hybrid materials, including bioconjugates but also various nanostructured organic/inorganic systems. Materials with controlled heterogeneity generated new morphologies (hexagonally perforated lamellae), self-healing systems, materials with hierarchical porosity and new delivery agents for nucleic acid. The research carried out had a broader impact on other disciplines. New advanced materials, such as nanostructured highly porous nitrogen enriched carbons have potential environmental and energy related applications as electrodes for oxygen reduction and hydrogen evolution reactions and can replace expensive platinum in fuel cell systems. They are also excellent components of dye-sensitized solar cells and supercapacitors and can be used for fast CO2 capture. Nanogels with degradable cationic core can be used for delivery of plasmid DNA and siRNA. Macroscopic gels can self-heal and rapidly respond to environmental stimuli. Densely grafted brushes act as supersoft elastomers with modulus (stiffness) similar to hydrogels but they will never dry as the networks are diluted by covalently attached short soft chains. The project involved education of graduate, undergraduate students and postdoctoral fellows. They were exposed to the most recent and advanced synthetic techniques in radical polymerization processes and characterization of polymeric materials. They regularly presented at semiannual Consortium meetings and also at national and international symposia. Their research was recognized by several ACS awards and they started successful careers in either academia or industry. PI research was also recognized by several international and ACS awards. The main dissemination process was through timely publications: 136 papers were published in peer-review journals. Our web site is very often visited (annually over 50,000 times) and provides introductory and advanced information on various controlled radical polymerization systems. Two ACS Meetings on Controlled Radical Polymerization were organized in 2011 and 2014 with ca. 100 oral and 100 poster presentations. Controlled radical polymerization is of significant commercial interest as evidenced by 55 international companies that have participated at the industrial consortium at Carnegie Mellon and 17 signed licenses resulting in new products commercialized in US, Europe and Japan. Last Modified: 06/04/2015 Submitted by: Krzysztof Matyjaszewski
